text: Yes -- one piece of content can rarely check off all your marketing goals, so it's good to set specific objectives for them like you said. It is tough when you don't have a ton of time/resources, but if you have solid bottom-of-the-funnel content, it's great to add in some tangential content to the mix to get more people aware of your brand

text: Hi all, I'd love to hear your thoughts on the "For Dummies" brand. Do you respect it? Like it? Never heard of it? We're thinking about writing one for a pretty dense topic but we want to get a read on people's perception of the brand...Please leave a comment or a thumbs up/thumbs down works. Thank you!

elements.text: Hi all, I'd love to hear your thoughts on the "For Dummies" brand. Do you respect it? Like it? Never heard of it? We're thinking about writing one for a pretty dense topic but we want to get a read on people's perception of the brand...Please leave a comment or a thumbs up/thumbs down works. Thank you!

text: You can actually work on a sponsored-ish piece of content with the For Dummies brand. We thought of doing that at my day job but the investment is pretty steep. Overall, I will say when I am looking at learning a good breadth of information around a topic, I will often turn to a For Dummies book for lots of good context, examples, etc.

text: Thanks <@U01J85VRKF1>! And yes, that's what we're thinking. We'd create one for lead gen, to bring to events, etc. I think many people know the brand but when they don't know it, people just wonder why it's calling them a dummy :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Thanks

! And yes, that's what we're thinking. We'd create one for lead gen, to bring to events, etc. I think many people know the brand but when they don't know it, people just wonder why it's calling them a dummy

text:
I grew up with it being a pretty prominent brand. I get that it's tongue in cheek.

Younger folks may not be familiar with it, but I can't see them taking it literally. The context is pretty clear. The art style and the look of the 'Dummy' screams "old" though. So you may lose some resonance that way. Sweet spot is probably Gen X... I can't speak to how it's interpreted outside of English speaking North America though.

text: I leaned pretty heavily on a For Dummies book for a project I worked on a couple of years ago, and was really impressed by the quality of the content. The branding is definitely a turnoff, though.

text: I have a question because I'm new at this. If you're working with an agency on, say, a blog, what level of editing do you expect to do on the draft they send over?

elements.text: I have a question because I'm new at this. If you're working with an agency on, say, a blog, what level of editing do you expect to do on the draft they send over?

text:
If I've briefed them well, I'd expect minor line editing and proofreading. Most of the structure and the bulk of the stuff should be in place. If they're new, you might expect them to need to learn any specific brand or industry terminology (unless, of course, you've also supplied a brand standards doc).

With no brief or a limited brief, you may need 1-2 round of revision with some structural back n forth too.

elements.text:
If I've briefed them well, I'd expect minor line editing and proofreading. Most of the structure and the bulk of the stuff should be in place. If they're new, you might expect them to need to learn any specific brand or industry terminology (unless, of course, you've also supplied a brand standards doc).

With no brief or a limited brief, you may need 1-2 round of revision with some structural back n forth too.

text: <@U01AHL8AGBB> Thank you! When you say "new," I'm assuming you mean, new to working with your company...how long would you give them to be ramped up?

elements.text: Thank you! When you say "new," I'm assuming you mean, new to working with your company...how long would you give them to be ramped up?

text:
Yeah, as in the relationship is new.

I'd expect pretty fast ramp, especially for minor detail things like terms. If by the third project they're still dropping the ball, I'd want to know why / what was unclear / where my brief is falling short / etc.

For more subjective things like tone, structure, etc... that's a kind of evolving practice. I'd still expect progress pretty quickly but would lower my standards a bit—what sounds good to me vs the agency writer(s) is likely not a critical detail. Audience resonation, preferably with hard metrics backing it, should have precedence over either of our opinions :slightly_smiling_face:

Audience resonation, preferably with hard metrics backing it, should have precedence over either of our opinions

text:
+1 on Jordy's comment, if the brief was thorough, I'd expect very minimal revisions.

I would also expect the agency to have a solid editorial process in place, maybe you could ask them what their workflow is for blog content and see if there are any gaps that mean the copy isn't coming back as you'd expected?

elements.text:
+1 on Jordy's comment, if the brief was thorough, I'd expect very minimal revisions.

I would also expect the agency to have a solid editorial process in place, maybe you could ask them what their workflow is for blog content and see if there are any gaps that mean the copy isn't coming back as you'd expected?

text: (Unless the gig is to write AS ME for my personal brand or whatever... then yeah, I need to like it... but in that case I'd cast the agency's role as "get me 75% of the way there and I'll Jordyify it myself.)

elements.text: (Unless the gig is to write AS ME for my personal brand or whatever... then yeah, I need to like it... but in that case I'd cast the agency's role as "get me 75% of the way there and I'll Jordyify it myself.)

text:
Generally, our pieces have 1 optional round of edits, and it's incredibly minimal (just picky details) once 2-3 pieces have been completed. About 75% of our clients never even look at what we write once the first month or so has passed because they're happy with upload-ready content. 

That isn't possible for everyone, but I would expect to need to make only a few edits unless it's the first or second piece you're getting on a very technical subject. Voice/tone may take a little longer to nail down, as Jordy said.

elements.text: Generally, our pieces have 1 optional round of edits, and it's incredibly minimal (just picky details) once 2-3 pieces have been completed. About 75% of our clients never even look at what we write once the first month or so has passed because they're happy with upload-ready content.

That isn't possible for everyone, but I would expect to need to make only a few edits unless it's the first or second piece you're getting on a very technical subject. Voice/tone may take a little longer to nail down, as Jordy said.

text:
Agency here.

We do 1 round of editing with 3 editors. Rarely do we need to send copy back to a writer unless they missed the mark completely, which means our content brief was bad.

Our editing includes grammar, formatting, internal links, title, h1, meta description, and applying clients’ style if applicable (we have an in-house style guide to deploy in the absence of a client’s).

Sometimes our clients will nip-tuck the copy we provide for little stylistic flourishes or polished terminology (we don’t claim to be experts in any single industry), but we always provide content that’s upload-ready from our POV.

Edit: Ditto as <@U024K88ECFN> here:
> About 75% of our clients never even look at what we write once the first month or so has passed because they’re happy with upload-ready content.

text: Thanks y'all, this is super helpful. I'm going to ask to be more involved in the initial brief. Still, right now I am giving them edits like, "You need to tell me what the article is about within the first two paragraphs" which I feel like is not something I should have to say, but it might just be it's unclear from the brief they're getting.

text:
<@U02CRMLF161> I like <@U02F43CAK5X>'s phrasing around tangental content. I've also heard people describe it as Authority, TOFU, Thought Leadership or Category Content.

I like to think of the average buying journey for an ICP and try to influence them with content across the entire journey. The earlier I can be top-of-mind or in the consideration set; the greater the odds for a close-won. Here is a graphic I used the other day to visualize this:

text: I have a unique experience, as I was asked to be an SME for an existing manuscript for them that I was hired to go through and verify. Working with them was fine, and I have no complaints. That said I would have some questions ready before investing any money or even having them publish a book traditionally, specifically around marketing/promotion and support expectations. One other things to consider is the crunch in shipping/logistics/and paper supply that is causing a lot of my author friends to move books back months or even years. I'm not sure if this is something that has been addressed, but you are happy to connect with me directly if you think I can offer any perspective. (Forgive any typos, I'm working from a glitchy bluetooth keyboard atm.)

One other things to consider is the crunch in shipping/logistics/and paper supply that is causing a lot of my author friends to move books back months or even years. I'm not sure if this is something that has been addressed, but you are happy to connect with me directly if you think I can offer any perspective. (Forgive any typos, I'm working from a glitchy bluetooth keyboard atm.)

text: I would also suggest that you do some competitive analysis of books that they've put out and see how they compare in terms of sales numbers and reviews against other books in their niche. They can be better or worse, with the low performers not performing well at all. Niche may be everything.
